awd_titl_txt: Type I: George Mason University Innovation Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project from George Mason University (Mason) creates an NSF I-Corps Site that will have a close affiliation with the Washington DC I-Corps Node. 

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. 
I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

An NSF I-Corps Site at Mason will aid in the creation of a commercialization facilitation infrastructure that will enhance the impact of existing and future entrepreneurial training and support activities and will demonstrate the value of entrepreneurship education to the Mason community. The I-Corps Site will impact the preparedness of university talent for roles in technology-based entrepreneurial enterprises and as such will be a critical ingredient of the economic success of Virginia and the United States as a whole. With an I-Corps Site, Mason's commercialization facilitation activities will support a shift from an economy dependent on traditional employers to an entrepreneurially-driven economy. As more startups begin to flourish, new jobs will be created and the career prospects of future graduates will be strengthened. On the national level, there is valid concern that the US is losing its standing as the global leader in technology. Mason's activities will counter this trend by teaching university researchers to think beyond traditional academic boundaries, thus enabling this group of highly-talented scientists to become drivers of innovation within technology-based entrepreneurial companies that they help to create.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
George Mason University’s I-Corps Site, funded by the National Science Foundation, has effectively leveraged the award to educate students and faculty on translating innovative ideas and discoveries into products and services that benefit society. As a result of our efforts, we have actively engaged our diverse academic community in innovation-focused activities, with the ongoing goal of expanding the pipeline of entrepreneurs at Mason and beyond. Participants have been introduced to the Lean Startup methodology through both didactic and hands-on experiential learning. Additionally, we have created a cohesive program structure and a phased developmental pathway for aspiring entrepreneurs. Most importantly, the Site grant has played a crucial role in cultivating an entrepreneurial culture at Mason and across Virginia through collaboration with a statewide network of incubators, mentors, and investors.

The grant has equipped student and faculty participants with resources for customer discovery and has allowed them to investigate various commercialization strategies, including founding companies, forming partnerships, and entering licensing agreements. We have also enhanced our impact by preparing teams to leverage additional resources, such as regional and National I-Corps programs, and to obtain funding from sources like the Virginia Innovation Partnership Corporation (VIPC) Higher Ed Commercialization Fund and commercialization initiatives from entities such as the NIH, DOD, and DOE. Our coordinated services, including ICAP and National I-Corps mentoring, have enabled several teams to position themselves favorably for SBIR/STTR and investor funding opportunities.

Our multi-pronged outreach initiatives have led to a significant rise in student engagement and increased interest in entrepreneurship across the university. By introducing I-Corps at departmental meetings, sparking conversations about the benefits of entrepreneurship, organizing pitch competitions and hackathons, and providing high-quality online resources, we have successfully generated substantial interest in our offerings. Since the program began, more than 1,000 students and faculty members from Mason and other Virginia universities have participated in I-Corps activities at Mason. 

In conclusion, the I-Corps Site award has empowered us to successfully integrate entrepreneurial thinking into the university’s culture while fostering collaborations with various partners to advance the program's objectives and enhance the regional entrepreneurial landscape.


Last Modified: 10/09/2024
Modified by: Ali Andalibi
